The brain reacts to emotions and feelings through the amygdala.

You don't have to be medical personnel, a doctor, or a scientist to know how your body works. 

The more you know how something work, the more you properly utilise it. 

Today, I decided to share an excerpt about a section of our brain called the amygdala and the frontal lobes. 

For a second, make sure you read it to the end. Then, you will understand what influences your decision-making process; every second, minute and hour. 

The idea here is to help you gain control of these brain sections going forward.

The amygdala is a collection of almond-shaped cells located near the base of the brain. Everyone has two cell groups in each hemisphere (or side) of the brain.

The amygdalae help to define and regulate emotions. They also preserve memories and attach them to specific feelings (happy, sad, joyous). You can refer to these as emotional remembrances.

The amygdala is part of the brain's limbic system. A limbic system is a group of complex, interconnected structures within the brain that are responsible for a person's emotional and behavioural responses.

The amygdala also activates the fight-or-flight response.

This response can help people in immediate physical danger react quickly for their safety and security. For example, the fight-or-flight response helped early humans respond to threats to avoid being injured or killed.

The amygdala activates this fight-or-flight response without any initiative from you. So when that part of your brain senses danger, it signals your brain to pump stress hormones, which prepares the body to fight for survival or flee to safety.

In these present circumstances, the fight-or-flight reaction is more likely to be activated by emotions such as anxiety, fear, attack, and anger.

The Frontal lobes
Often, we call the amygdala "reflect actions"; you don't control it. It happens automatically. 

On the other hand, the front lobes allow you to evaluate your emotions and then consciously respond to your experiences and judgment. These responses are not automatic, unlike the ones provoked by the amygdala.

The frontal lobes are located in the brain's cerebral cortex. This brain area regulates voluntary actions like reasoning, thinking, movement, decision-making, and planning. Unlike the amygdala, the frontal lobes are more rational in processing information.

When faced with physical threats, the amygdala automatically jumps to the fight-or-flight response, but the front lobes process the information you're receiving to help you determine if the danger is real. 

Conversely, if the threat isn't immediate, the frontal lobes help you decide what to do in response to the stress.

Sometimes, when you react angrily or emotionally and later feel embarrassed and regretful, know that your amygdala is at work. 

But how can you teach your brain to restrain these auto actions and leverage the frontal lobes from taking rational decisions?

Watch out for my following email. 

Don't take this as a usual thing. 

Nurturing the brain is the best gift anyone can ever have. Because the brain is what define who we are. 

Now imagine you helping yourself or your children (from a tender age) learn how to control emotions through digital skills?

It's a gift money cannot buy. It requires constant training

We want to help you nurture your brain with design and coding skills. So you or your kids can create solutions that will further help the world.

Schedule a free call with us now, and we will show you how you or your kids can learn to design or code in the next 12 weeks. calendly.com/instincthub/30min

Noah Olatoye
instincthub.com

It is annoying, {{first_name}}.

One day, I tried to withdraw my last card from the ATM, and all I could see was a debit alert without any dispensed cash. 

I was pissed and upset. 

To make the matter worse, it was a weekend. 

Then I didn't have a technology idea; if I did, I won't be too worried because at least I would guess what was wrong.

Not knowing how technologies works is like being in the dark.

For a second, have you ever wondered how the banking system works?

Seriously, it is not that complicated.

Imagine when you want to withdraw some extra cash from the ATM.

Bank operators get signals when a customer from Bank A uses the ATM (Automated Teller Machine) of Bank B; through APIs, both banks can reconcile and quickly debit your account while you, on the other hand, get the cash in return.

#### What is Python?
Python is a programming language used for general software development purposes that was created by Guido van Rossum in 1991. 

Python is for object-oriented (can access and store data and code) , functional (make it do something, procedural (create a sequence) and reflective programming. If you don’t know what that is, don't worry, before the end of the 30 Days with Python, you will get acquainted with it.

How did it go, {{first_name}}?

We learnt about the `Print()` function:

The Python `print()` function takes in any number of parameters, and prints them out on one line of text. 

The items are each converted to text form, separated by spaces, and there is a single `'\n'` (new line) at the end (the "newline" char). 

When called with zero parameters, `print()` just prints the '\n' and nothing else.

email_subject: [Part 2] Most effective ways to help your child succeed in school
description:
Hello {{first_name}}, 

There is so much to think about each school year, but above all else, these simple rules can help keep you focused on what’s most important for school success.

## Do
- Focus on the process, not the product.
- Encourage kids to self-advocate.
- Keep a long-term perspective.
- Maintain a healthy sleep schedule.
- Love the child you have, not the child you wish you had.

## Don’t
- Over-schedule.
- Worship grades.
- Encourage helplessness.
- Compare kids to one another.
- Love kids based on their performance.

In my following email, I will share what should be your priority (watch out for my mail).

email_subject: [Part 3] Most effective ways to help your child succeed in school
description:
Value the Process Over the Product, {{first_name}}!

Naturally, very young children are self-motivated to learn and explore new things. 

They are at the very beginning of their lifelong quest to understand and gain mastery of the world around them. 

As parents, this should always ring a bell.

As they reach out, fall and get back up again, they gain a heightened sense of mastery, competence and self-efficacy. 

Somewhere around the nursery, however, parents and teachers begin to undermine this process by devaluing the process of learning and replacing it with a mad dash for the end products. 

Suddenly, the intrinsic motivators of natural curiosity, competence and self-efficacy are less valuable than extrinsic motivators such as stickers, points and grades. 

Unfortunately, extrinsic motivators undermine kids’ desire to learn over the long term. 

Want your kid to lose interest in school? Pay them for their A’s and worship at the altar of grades. 

If you’d instead like your kids to remain curious and hungry for mastery, here are some tips for re-orienting kids’ priorities.

### 1. Keep report cards off social media and the refrigerator: 
We can tell our kids that we value learning all we want, but when we gush over grades and stick them to the refrigerator, we show them that what we love most are the grades. 

Of course, most parents are stuck with grades, even if they are flawed and incomplete indicators of learning and what’s known as an “extrinsic motivator,” which has been shown to reduce motivation over the long term, undermine creativity, and encourage creativity cheating. 

Some schools have moved away from letter-based grades and use reports focused on mastery- or standards-based evaluations to help parents and kids focus on what’s being learned rather than a grade. 

No matter what kind of report your child gets, humble-bragging about it on social media only feeds parental competition;

It raises the pressure for kids and teaches them that your love and approval are contingent on their report card content. 

Let us continue tomorrow on their process to get a good grade (watch out for my mail). 


Schedule a free 30 minutes strategy session with one of my team.

We will show you exactly the steps you need to take. Follow the link: [Click Here](calendly.com/instincthub/30min)

The logical operators `AND` and `OR` specify the relationship between operands in a logical expression. 

The logical operator `NOT` is used to negate logical variables or constants. 

`AND` and `OR` are the reserved values used to specify the relationship between operands in a logical expression.

email_subject: [Part 4] Most effective ways to help your child succeed in school
description:
Keep to the process, {{first_name}}!

### 2. Focus on the process they used to get that grade. 

When we invest less energy and emotion in the number or letter at the top of the page, we can begin to ask our children questions such as;

What did you do to get this grade? 

Which study techniques worked for you and which ones did not? 

What are you going to do differently next time? 


### 3. Look forward, not back. 
The best question parents can ask when faced with a grade, whether high or low, is: 

How are you going to use this experience to be better next time? 

This technique works particularly well for anxious and overly perfectionist kids because they can get stuck in a negative feedback loop, obsessing wholly on the numbers and grades. 

Helping them shift their focus back to the process can alleviate that anxiety, particularly when we help them prioritize the aspects of learning they can control. 

Let us continue tomorrow by sharing our failure with the kids (watch out for my mail).

email_subject: [Part 5] Most effective ways to help your child succeed in school
description:
Be strategic, {{first_name}}! Please talk about your failures and successes with your kids. By showing them that you, too, have invested in the process of learning.

_**If you criticise yourself over failures, so will they.**_

If, however, they see you being brave and learning from your mistakes so you can be better next time, so will they.

### Value Goals Over Grades One easy way to invest in the process is to set goals individually and as a family. Try to do this at the beginning of a new school year, on the first day of the month, or at the start of a new season. Keep the discussion light and low-pressure. This process isn’t about getting better grades; it’s about supporting learning as a family.

_**Please help them to set three short goals!**_

Everyone (yes, that means parents, too) sets three short-term, achievable goals oriented around tasks and improvements under your control. Lets continue on Monday, {{first_name}}! We will look at examples of some of the goals you can set for your kids.

#### Schedule a free 30 minutes strategy session with one of my team. We will show you exactly the steps you need to take. Follow the link: [Click Here](calendly.com/instincthub/30min)

email_subject: [Part 6] Most effective ways to help your child succeed in school
description:
Hello {{first_name}},
Lets talk about example goals you can set for your kids. The greatest mistake we make is watch our kids set some unrealistic goals for themselves. For example, “I’m going to get all A's this semester” is too broad and difficult to control. Instead, try “I’m going to ask for help in math more often,” “I will plan one extra help session a week,” or “I will practice my multiplication three extra times this month.” Please don't set a scary ambition for them. The best way to help these kids is to be an example. We can’t hope to convince our children to be emotionally and intellectually brave unless they see us do the same, so set some goals that get you out of your comfort zone. Take guitar or dance or Spanish lessons, try an activity you have never tried before, or pick up a new hobby. This is, after all, how we expand our cognitive potential and make new connections in our brains that can help us become stronger, smarter and more efficient learners. One thing to note, before you set new goals, make sure you review their performance with the previous goals. Do this at least once a month or once a semester. Lets wrap it up here {{first_name}}. #### Schedule a free 30 minutes strategy session with one of my team. We will show you exactly the steps you need to take. Follow the link: [Click Here](calendly.com/instincthub/30min)

We learnt about the **`Nested Lists`** in Python

A list can contain any sort object, even another list (sublist), which in turn can contain sublists themselves, and so on. This is known as nested list.

You can use them to arrange data into hierarchical structures.

email_subject: Coding vs programming | exchange professionalism for sofa
description:
Here are this week's 2 links that are worth your time:

1. **Coding vs Programming - The Unique Differences:** often, people can easily be offended when you call them a coder, even though nothing is wrong with the term. First, however, you must know what you are saying to people. [https://instincthub.com/coding-vs-programming-the-unique-differences/](https://instincthub.com/coding-vs-programming-the-unique-differences/)

2. **How we exchange professionalism for sofa - the cost of remote work:** Out of ten people, perhaps only zero point five of the ten will look up physical work these days. It is not a bad thing; in fact, Covid-19 gave humanity another perspective on life and how we can save time and resources while building a unique product and team. [https://instincthub.com/how-we-exchange-professionalism-for-sofa-the-cost-of-remote-work/](https://instincthub.com/how-we-exchange-professionalism-for-sofa-the-cost-of-remote-work/)

**Quote of the Week:** “A very simple but particularly useful technique for finding the cause of a problem is simply to explain it to someone else. The other person should look over your shoulder at the screen, and nod his or her head constantly (like a rubber duck bobbing up and down in a bathtub).” — Andrew Hunt and David Thomas, authors of the 1999 book The Pragmatic Programmer

Dear {{first_name}},

I really want you to see this video!

I'm super excited you did that you downloaded my eBook!

And I hope you are getting the best of it.

I've several things in stock for you! In the next few days, I will be sharing the most optimised way you can help your kids learn technological skills.

So make sure you don't miss any of them.

You might be thinking, "why is this guy doing all these things for free?"

Well, the simple answer for me is, I love kids.

I hate to see kids go through the same educational system we went through during the young age that failed us.

Dear {{first_name}},
I hope this email finds you well. I frequently share information that will help to keep your motivation afloat. It is the end of the week, and I think you need this information. I recently tried researching why most people end up not finishing what they started learning, especially when acquiring technical skills. I was able to get two profound reasons:
**1. Lack of patience:** adapting to new skills is not for the weak and for people looking to get rich quickly. Every new skill (depending on the complexity) requires patience and consistency before things would start making sense. I noticed the sets of people who struggle a lot overwork their brains by focusing on imaginary outcomes instead of completing the day-to-day activities involved.
**2. Wrong learning approach:** this is very common; imagine learning to drift a car when you've not learned how to drive on a typical street or highway! Imagine the frustration this kind of approach will bring! To learn car drifting, you must learn how to drive and perfect your driving for several months before considering drifting. Every new skill has its fundamentals. Never underestimate foundation knowledge. They are the building blocks for every perfection. Individuals who lack patience or learn the wrong way often get frustrated and quit after this experience.

email_subject: You have no boundaries with Tech Skills
description:
{{first_name}}, you don't have boundaries with tech skills.

From web development to product design to app development and many more. 

And one news that I'm sure will excite you is that "there is no late comer in tech."

Even if you get interested at age 50, I can assure you there are a lot of resources that will help you get to your desired destination in the world of tech. 

There is space for everybody in the tech world, and you don't have to be a graduate of computer science to learn tech skills. 

Though the world of tech is a vast field, there are different skills in the world of tech.

Let me do a quick recap on two areas in the world of tech: 

### 1. Web development
Web development in simple English is the process of building and maintaining a website for the internet that is accessed through a web browser. 

As a web developer, your job is mainly to build websites using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. 

In web development there are two aspects of web development: 

- Front-end: This is the part of the web you see on the browser
- Back-end: This is the part of the website you don't see; it deals with a lot of the logic and functionality. Remember the restaurant description in the book? 

### 2. Mobile Development 
This is one of the last decade's most popular forms of coding. 

This is because you can't do without apps on your mobile phone. Imagine having a phone, and there are no apps on it?? 

Boring right?? 

Now you know why these skills are relevant. 

There are two main categories of mobile devices, which are: 
iOS
Android

Are you excited about the boundless opportunities hovering around tech?

If your answer is yes, let us discuss how you can begin a tech career in 12 weeks. [Pick a date and time here](https://instincthub.com/calls/30/).

{{first_name}}, web developers worldwide are solving problems, and job relevance is improving. 

A web developer's job is to create websites. Web developers always fall into one of these three categories: 

### 1. Front-end web developers: 
Think of these individuals as the people in charge of an eatery's open space. The customers can buy food and decide to eat there or request a takeaway. 

The front-end developers work on the visual part of the website - the pages people interact with. They design the layout of each page, integrate graphics, and use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to enhance the site's interactivity.

### 2. Back-end web developers: 
Think of these individuals as the people in charge of an eatery's kitchen. They do the behind-the-seen work to ensure the food is appealing, edible and delicious. 

Back-end developers make sure the users and business data are properly managed. They create structure and logic that communicate with the front-end and other third parties applications.

### 3. Full-stack developer: 
These individuals do the work of the chef in an eatery kitchen and that of the people in charge of the open space.

They do the work of both a back-end and front-end developer. These developers know and can implement all it takes to build an entire web application.  

Interestingly {{first_name}}, you could be one of these great individuals! 

Let us discuss how you can begin a tech career in 12 weeks. [Pick a date and time here.](https://instincthub.com/calls/30/)

{{first_name}},

As I said in one of my previous emails, mobile development is one of the most popular forms of coding and here are the two categories of mobile devices we have:

**iOS** is a mobile operating system developed and distributed by Apple Inc. It was initially released in 2007 with the iPhone and today runs on many other devices, including the iPod Touch, iPad, and Apple TV.

**Android** is an open-source, Linux-based mobile operating system. Android was developed by the Open Handset Alliance, led by Google and featured contributions from many other companies.

{{first_name}}, web developers worldwide are solving problems, and job relevance is improving. 

A web developer's job is to create websites. Web developers always fall into one of these three categories: 

### 1. Front-end web developers: 
Think of these individuals as the people in charge of an eatery's open space. The customers can buy food and decide to eat there or request a takeaway. 

The front-end developers work on the visual part of the website - the pages people interact with. They design the layout of each page, integrate graphics, and use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to enhance the site's interactivity.

### 2. Back-end web developers: 
Think of these individuals as the people in charge of an eatery's kitchen. They do the behind-the-seen work to ensure the food is appealing, edible and delicious. 

Back-end developers make sure the users and business data are properly managed. They create structure and logic that communicate with the front-end and other third parties applications.

### 3. Full-stack developer: 
These individuals do the work of the chef in an eatery kitchen and that of the people in charge of the open space.

They do the work of both a back-end and front-end developer. These developers know and can implement all it takes to build an entire web application.  

Interestingly {{first_name}}, you could be one of these great individuals!

{{first_name}}, Wrapping up the story of Jason H., who stabbed his school teacher, he pleaded not guilty in the law court. Suppose you missed my previous email. [See the full story here.](https://instincthub.com/why-did-david-get-stabbed/) Before the jury, Jason claimed he had been planning to commit suicide since he got the test score. And only went to the teacher to express the difficulty he was facing; he was going to harm himself. The teacher, on the other hand, has a different narration. He claimed Jason was utterly aware of his action to hurt him with the knife he brought from home just because he wasn't satisfied with the bad grade. ### The judge found Jason innocent! An expert hired by the defence testified that the wound near Pologruto's collarbone was consistent with Jason's assertion. But Pologruto testified that the student had lunged at him from behind the physics lab. As a result, he had to wrestle the knife from the student to avoid being more severely injured. Five psychologists and psychiatrists appointed by the prosecution and defence agreed that Jason was psychotic at the time of the stabbing. Jason changed his school to the American Heritage School. He took fewer courses but continued taking advanced courses, raising his grade point average to 4.614. Perfect scores in regular classes would result in a 4.0 average. To date, Pologruto still struggles to make sense of what happened. In 1992, the story was published in [New York Times.](https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/23/us/student-who-stabbed-teacher-has-a-warning.html) "Jason never even admitted that he did anything," he said. "The only thing he said was, 'I'm sorry you got hurt in my suicide attempt.' " The question is, how could someone this intelligent do something so horrible? It doesn't make sense, really! Academy intellect has little to do with our emotions. The reason you would see someone in a luxury car with a clean dress; the next moment, the person is out of the car, pulling off their shoes to fight with someone who almost bashed their vehicle on the highway. Next time you find yourself in an unpleasant situation, don't act out of anger alone; let your brain's rational (frontal lobe) and irrational (amygdala) parts communicate. When these two partners effectively communicate, emotional intelligence rises.

Dear {{first_name}},

Seeing how young people aspire to leave the country isn't comforting. But, whenever these individuals get their visas, it is good news. However, from a business owner's perspective, it is one man down. 

I was talking to some young and a few older people, and I could sense from their responses that they see their future in another man's country. 

In fact, just this month, over three people in my circle left Nigeria entirely without a plan to return.

One of the best ways to keep your company growing is to retain core talent. Here are two ways to keep your best employees on board.

## 1. Pay above-average salaries
One of the most obvious ways to retain top workers is to offer better-than-average salaries and excellent benefits. This can lock employees in and encourage them to stick around for the pay and perks alone. You can also provide a specific retention bonus to give the incentive to stay with the company.

## 2. Offer the ability to grow
It may be tempting to keep your best employees in the same position with the same duties. If they are performing above expectations, why change what they are doing? But employees who do the same tasks again and again can also grow complacent. If they ask for more or change things, entertain the idea seriously.

In wrapping up, two crucial questions to ask are why are they leaving in the first place? What can be done to prevent those that are still here from changing their minds? 

Actioning the answers to these questions will create a more sustainable working environment. 

I'm Noah Olatoye, a Nigerian programmer and entrepreneur. Chief executive and founder of [instincthub.com](https://instincthub.com) - we help individuals and corporate organisations upskill in achieving success through technology skills.

This is an introductory email; I will be reaching out to you on ways we can help others achieve success. 

Thank you

Since then, the software has become the industry standard in raster graphics editing and digital art as a whole. In this lesson, you will learn how to use this powerful tool.
